discussion.content: I agree with the answer but I am not conformable with the framework. Having one exit portrays danger for the examiner or investigator during an emergency...

questions.question_text: Steven has been given the task of designing a computer forensics lab for the company he works for. He has found documentation on all aspects of how to design a lab except the number of exits needed. How many exits should Steven include in his design for the computer forensics lab?
Sniffers that place NICs in promiscuous mode work at what layer of the OSI model?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Layer 2 is the data link layer. The three elements of the Layer 2 Security policy are promiscuous mode, MAC address changes, and forged transmits. In non-promiscuous mode, a guest adapter listens to traffic only on its own MAC address
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.0/com.vmware.vsphere.hostclient.doc/GUID-74E2059A-CC5E-4B06-81B5-3881C80E46CE.html#:~:text=Layer%202%20is%20the%20data%20link%20layer.%20The,to%20traffic%20only%20on%20its%20own%20MAC%20address.

On an Active Directory network using NTLM authentication, where on the domain controllers are the passwords stored?

discussion.content:
The Ntds.dit file is a database that stores Active Directory data, including information about user objects, groups, and group membership. It includes the password hashes for all users in the domain.

By extracting these hashes, it is possible to use tools such as Mimikatz to perform pass-the-hash attacks, or tools like Hashcat to crack these passwords. The extraction and cracking of these passwords can be performed offline, so they will be undetectable. Once an attacker has extracted these hashes, they are able to act as any user on the domain, including Domain Administrators.
https://www.ultimatewindowssecurity.com/blog/default.aspx?d=10/2017

NTLM user authentication
 User records are stored in the security accounts manager (SAM) database or in the Active Directory database. Each user account is associated with two passwords: the LAN Manager-compatible password and the Windows password. Each password is encrypted and stored in the SAM database or in the Active Directory database.
ntds.dit is not an answer, so the next best one would be SAM.
Domain controllers store passwords for domain accounts in ntds.dit not the SAM file.
